canonical_explanation.text: Practical geometry involves constructing geometric figures accurately using instruments such as a ruler, compass, divider, protractor, and set squares. Key constructions at this level include drawing line segments of given lengths, copying line segments, constructing perpendiculars (at a point on a line and from an external point), constructing the perpendicular bisector of a line segment, drawing angles of given measures, bisecting angles, constructing special angles (60, 90, 120 degrees) using a compass, and drawing circles of given radii.
rules: Rule 1: A line segment of given length can be drawn using a ruler, or copied using a compass by transferring the opening.
Rule 2: The perpendicular bisector of a line segment passes through its midpoint and is at 90 degrees to it. Every point on it is equidistant from the two endpoints.
Rule 3: To construct a 60-degree angle, draw an arc from the vertex, then with the same radius draw an arc from the point where the first arc meets the ray. The intersection gives 60 degrees.
Rule 4: An angle bisector divides an angle into two equal parts. Constructed by drawing arcs from both arms and connecting the vertex to the intersection.
Rule 5: A circle is constructed by fixing the compass opening to the required radius and rotating it 360 degrees around the centre point.

questions.question_text: To draw a line segment of length 5.6 cm, which instrument is most directly used?
questions.explanation_correct: A ruler is used to draw a line segment of a given length by marking the start and end points and drawing a line between them.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A protractor measures angles, not lengths. A set square is for drawing perpendiculars and specific angles. A divider compares lengths. A ruler directly draws a segment of given length.

questions.question_text: To copy a line segment AB onto another ray, you use:
questions.explanation_correct: To copy a line segment, open the compass to the length of AB, then transfer that opening onto the new ray using the compass. A ruler is used to draw the ray.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Copying a line segment accurately requires a compass to capture the exact length and a ruler or straightedge to draw the line.

questions.question_text: When drawing a line segment using a ruler, you should start measuring from:

options.text: Any mark, as long as you count correctly

questions.explanation_correct: You should start from the 0 cm mark on the ruler for accurate measurement. While starting from any mark works if you subtract correctly, the 0 mark is the standard and most reliable method.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The edge of the ruler may not align with the 0 mark. Starting from the 0 cm mark ensures accurate measurement of the segment.

questions.question_text: A compass can be used to draw a line segment of a given length without measuring with a ruler first.
questions.explanation_correct: To draw a line segment of a specific length, you first need to open the compass to the required length using a ruler, then transfer it. The compass alone cannot measure a specific length from scratch.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A compass by itself cannot determine a specific measurement like 5 cm. You need a ruler first to set the compass opening to the desired length.

questions.question_text: A perpendicular to a line at a point on it makes an angle of:
questions.explanation_correct: A perpendicular line meets another line at exactly 90 degrees (a right angle).
questions.explanation_incorrect: By definition, a perpendicular line meets the given line at 90 degrees.

questions.question_text: The perpendicular bisector of a line segment:

options.text: Passes through the midpoint and is at 90 degrees to the segment
Divides the segment into two unequal parts

questions.explanation_correct: The perpendicular bisector of a line segment passes through its midpoint and is perpendicular (90 degrees) to it.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A perpendicular bisector does two things: it bisects the segment (passes through the midpoint dividing it into two equal parts) and is perpendicular to it.

questions.question_text: Every point on the perpendicular bisector of a line segment AB is equidistant from A and B.
questions.explanation_correct: This is a key property of the perpendicular bisector. Any point on it is exactly the same distance from both endpoints A and B.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This is indeed true. The perpendicular bisector is the locus of all points equidistant from the two endpoints.

questions.question_text: Which instrument is used to measure and draw angles?
questions.explanation_correct: A protractor is the instrument used to measure and draw angles of given measures.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A ruler measures length, a compass draws circles and arcs, a divider compares lengths. A protractor is specifically designed for measuring and constructing angles.

questions.question_text: An angle bisector divides an angle into:

options.text: A right angle and an acute angle

questions.explanation_correct: An angle bisector is a ray that divides an angle into two equal parts.
questions.explanation_incorrect: By definition, to bisect means to divide into two equal parts. An angle bisector divides the angle into two equal halves.

questions.question_text: Using a compass and ruler, an angle of 60 degrees can be constructed by:

options.text: Drawing an arc from the vertex, then an arc of the same radius from the point on the first arc
Drawing a diagonal of a square

questions.explanation_correct: To construct 60 degrees: draw a ray, use the compass to draw an arc from the vertex, then keeping the same radius, draw an arc from where the first arc meets the ray. The intersection point gives 60 degrees.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Two perpendicular lines give 90 degrees, not 60. A protractor is a measuring tool, not a construction tool. The correct method uses equal arcs from the vertex and the point on the ray.

questions.question_text: To draw a circle, the compass opening represents the:
questions.explanation_correct: The distance between the compass point and the pencil tip represents the radius of the circle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The compass opening is the distance from the centre to any point on the circle, which is the radius. The diameter would be twice the compass opening.

questions.question_text: To draw a circle of diameter 8 cm, the compass should be opened to:
questions.explanation_correct: Radius = Diameter / 2 = 8 / 2 = 4 cm. The compass opening should be set to the radius, which is 4 cm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The compass opening is the radius, not the diameter. Radius = 8 ÷ 2 = 4 cm.

questions.question_text: When drawing a circle with a compass, the pointed end is placed at the centre of the circle.
questions.explanation_correct: The pointed (needle) end of the compass is placed at the centre, and the pencil end traces the circumference at a fixed distance (radius).
questions.explanation_incorrect: This is correct. The needle end stays fixed at the centre while the pencil end rotates around it.

questions.question_text: A divider is used in geometry to:
questions.explanation_correct: A divider has two pointed ends and is used to compare or transfer lengths accurately.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Angles are measured with a protractor. Circles are drawn with a compass. Parallel lines need a ruler and set square. A divider is for comparing or transferring lengths.

questions.question_text: If you bisect a 90-degree angle, each resulting angle measures:
questions.explanation_correct: Bisecting means dividing into two equal parts. 90 ÷ 2 = 45 degrees.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An angle bisector divides the angle into two equal halves. 90 ÷ 2 = 45 degrees.

questions.question_text: To draw a line segment of 7.3 cm, you mark one point at 0 cm and the other at ______ cm on the ruler.
questions.explanation_correct: Starting from 0 cm, the endpoint at 7.3 cm gives a segment of exactly 7.3 cm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Starting from the 0 mark, you measure 7.3 cm and mark the endpoint there.

questions.question_text: To construct a perpendicular to a line at a given point on it using a compass, how many arcs do you need to draw in total?
questions.explanation_correct: Step 1: Draw an arc from the given point to mark two points on the line (1 arc with two intersection points). Step 2 and 3: From each of these two points, draw arcs above the line that intersect (2 arcs). Total = 3 arcs.
questions.explanation_incorrect: You need 3 arcs: one arc from the given point to find two equidistant points on the line, then two arcs from these points to find the intersection above the line.

questions.question_text: To construct an angle of 120 degrees using a compass, you can:

options.text: Construct two 60-degree angles adjacent to each other
Construct a right angle and add 45 degrees

questions.explanation_correct: 120 = 60 + 60. You can construct a 60-degree angle, then from the same vertex, construct another 60-degree angle adjacent to it to get 120 degrees.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bisecting 180 gives 90, not 120. Tripling 30 requires precise 30-degree construction first. 90 + 45 = 135, not 120. Two adjacent 60-degree angles give 120.

questions.question_text: Which of these is NOT a standard instrument in a geometry box?
questions.explanation_correct: A geometry box typically contains a ruler, compass, divider, protractor, and set squares. A calculator is not a geometry instrument.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ruler, compass, and protractor are all standard geometry instruments. A calculator is a computing device, not a geometric construction tool.

questions.question_text: To draw a circle of radius 3.5 cm, the compass opening should be set to ______ cm.
questions.explanation_correct: The compass opening equals the radius of the circle. So for a radius of 3.5 cm, the compass is opened to 3.5 cm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The compass opening is the radius. For a circle of radius 3.5 cm, open the compass to 3.5 cm.

questions.question_text: Ravi wants to copy line segment PQ (length 6.4 cm) onto a ray RS using a compass. What is the correct first step after drawing ray RS?

options.text: Open the compass to 6.4 cm using the ruler
Place the compass at the midpoint of PQ
Draw a circle of radius 6.4 cm

questions.explanation_correct: To copy a segment, first open the compass to the length of PQ (6.4 cm). Then place the compass point at R on ray RS and draw an arc. The point where the arc meets the ray is 6.4 cm from R.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The first step is to capture the length of PQ in the compass. You open the compass to 6.4 cm, then transfer it onto the ray.

questions.question_text: Sneha constructs the perpendicular bisector of a line segment AB of length 10 cm. At what distance from A does the bisector cross AB?
questions.explanation_correct: The perpendicular bisector crosses AB at its midpoint. The midpoint of a 10 cm segment is at 10 ÷ 2 = 5 cm from either end.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A bisector divides into two equal parts. The midpoint of a 10 cm segment is at 5 cm from each endpoint.

questions.question_text: To construct an angle of 30 degrees using a compass and ruler, you should first construct:
questions.explanation_correct: Construct a 60-degree angle using a compass, then bisect it to get 60 ÷ 2 = 30 degrees.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Trisecting an angle with compass is not a standard construction. The standard method is to construct 60 degrees and bisect it to get 30 degrees.

questions.question_text: What angle can you construct by bisecting a 60-degree angle twice?
questions.explanation_correct: First bisection: 60 ÷ 2 = 30 degrees. Second bisection: 30 ÷ 2 = 15 degrees.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bisecting twice means dividing by 2 twice: 60 ÷ 2 = 30, then 30 ÷ 2 = 15 degrees.

questions.question_text: To construct a perpendicular from an external point P to a line l, you first:

options.text: Draw arcs from P that intersect line l at two points
Measure the distance from P to l with a ruler
Draw a circle with centre on l
Draw a line parallel to l through P

questions.explanation_correct: With compass centred at P, draw an arc of suitable radius that intersects line l at two points. Then from these two points, draw arcs below the line that intersect. Join P to this intersection for the perpendicular.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The first step is to draw arcs from P that cut line l at two points, establishing two equidistant points on the line from which to construct the perpendicular.

questions.question_text: Ankit wants to draw two concentric circles with radii 3 cm and 5 cm. What must remain the same for both circles?
questions.explanation_correct: Concentric circles share the same centre but have different radii. The compass needle stays at the same centre point for both circles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Concentric means 'same centre'. The radii differ (3 cm and 5 cm), so the compass opening changes, but the centre point remains the same.

questions.question_text: Meera drew a line segment of 8.2 cm but needs one of 4.1 cm. She can obtain it by:

options.text: Constructing the perpendicular bisector of her segment
Erasing half the segment by guessing
Drawing an arc of radius 8.2 cm

questions.explanation_correct: The perpendicular bisector of a segment passes through its midpoint. The midpoint of an 8.2 cm segment is at 4.1 cm. So constructing the perpendicular bisector gives the midpoint, and the half-segment is 4.1 cm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 4.1 cm is exactly half of 8.2 cm. The perpendicular bisector finds the exact midpoint, giving two 4.1 cm halves.

questions.question_text: To construct an angle of 90 degrees using only a compass and ruler (without a protractor), you can:

options.text: Construct a 60-degree angle and add a 30-degree angle to it
Construct 60-degree angle and subtract from 180 degrees
Construct the perpendicular bisector of any line segment

questions.explanation_correct: Construct 60 degrees, then bisect it to get 30 degrees. Place the 30-degree angle adjacent to the 60-degree angle: 60 + 30 = 90 degrees. Alternatively, you can construct the perpendicular bisector, but option A directly answers the question.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 60 + 30 = 90. Construct 60 degrees, bisect it to get 30, and add them together. Option D also works conceptually but describes a different construction.

questions.question_text: The perpendicular bisector of a line segment AB can be constructed using only a compass and a straightedge (no measurements needed).
questions.explanation_correct: Yes. Draw arcs of equal radius from A and B on both sides of AB. The line through the two intersection points is the perpendicular bisector. No measurement is needed — just equal compass openings from both endpoints.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This is true. The construction uses arcs of equal radius from both endpoints. The radius just needs to be more than half of AB; no specific measurement is required.

questions.question_text: Priya draws a circle of radius 4 cm. The diameter of her circle is:
questions.explanation_correct: Diameter = 2 x Radius = 2 x 4 = 8 cm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The diameter is always twice the radius. Diameter = 2 x 4 = 8 cm.

questions.question_text: If you bisect an angle of 120 degrees, each half measures:
questions.explanation_correct: Bisecting means dividing into two equal parts. 120 ÷ 2 = 60 degrees.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An angle bisector divides the angle into two equal halves. 120 ÷ 2 = 60 degrees.

questions.question_text: To draw a triangle with sides 3 cm, 4 cm, and 5 cm, which instruments are essential?
questions.explanation_correct: To construct a triangle with given sides, you use a ruler to draw the base and a compass to mark arcs at the required distances for the other two sides.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A ruler alone can draw one side but cannot accurately locate the third vertex. A compass is needed to draw arcs of the correct lengths from both endpoints of the base.

questions.question_text: Aarav needs to construct a perpendicular at the endpoint A of a line segment AB. Which method works?

options.text: Construct the perpendicular bisector of AB
Draw arcs from A on the line, then arcs from those points above the line
Draw a circle centred at B
Use only a protractor to draw 90 degrees at A

questions.explanation_correct: To construct a perpendicular at endpoint A: from A, draw arcs that mark points on the line on both sides of A (or extending beyond), then from those points draw arcs above the line. Their intersection gives the perpendicular direction from A.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The perpendicular bisector goes through the midpoint, not the endpoint. A circle centred at B doesn't help. The standard compass construction involves arcs from A and then from the points marked on the line.

questions.question_text: If you bisect a right angle, each resulting angle measures ______ degrees.
questions.explanation_correct: A right angle is 90 degrees. Bisecting it gives 90 ÷ 2 = 45 degrees.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bisecting 90 degrees gives 90 ÷ 2 = 45 degrees.

questions.question_text: Kavya draws a circle of radius 5 cm. What is the longest chord she can draw in this circle?
questions.explanation_correct: The longest chord of a circle is the diameter. Diameter = 2 x radius = 2 x 5 = 10 cm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The diameter is the longest chord in any circle. Diameter = 2 x 5 = 10 cm.

questions.question_text: Point P is on the perpendicular bisector of segment AB. If PA = 7 cm, then PB equals:
questions.explanation_correct: Every point on the perpendicular bisector of AB is equidistant from A and B. So if PA = 7 cm, then PB = 7 cm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The key property of the perpendicular bisector is that any point on it is equidistant from both endpoints. PA = PB = 7 cm.

questions.question_text: When constructing a perpendicular bisector, the compass opening must be:

options.text: Exactly equal to the segment length
More than half the segment length

questions.explanation_correct: The compass must be opened to more than half the segment length so that arcs from both endpoints can intersect. If the opening is half or less, the arcs will not cross.
questions.explanation_incorrect: For the arcs from both endpoints to intersect, the compass radius must be greater than half the segment length.

questions.question_text: Using a compass and straightedge only, which of the following angles CANNOT be constructed?
questions.explanation_correct: 15° = 60° ÷ 4 (bisect twice). 75° = 60° + 15°. 120° = 2 x 60°. All these can be constructed. But 40° cannot be constructed using only a compass and straightedge because it requires trisecting 120° or constructing a non-standard angle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 15, 75, and 120 degrees can all be derived from 60-degree constructions with bisection and addition. 40 degrees cannot be constructed with compass and straightedge alone.

questions.question_text: In the construction of the perpendicular bisector of AB, arcs are drawn from A and B with equal radii. The two intersection points of these arcs are called P and Q. Which statement is true?

options.text: PQ passes through the midpoint of AB and is perpendicular to AB
PQ bisects AB but is not perpendicular to it
PQ has the same length as AB

questions.explanation_correct: The line through P and Q is the perpendicular bisector of AB. It passes through the midpoint of AB and meets AB at 90 degrees.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both P and Q are equidistant from A and B (they lie on the perpendicular bisector). The line PQ bisects AB at right angles.

questions.question_text: To construct an angle of 105 degrees using compass and ruler, which combination works?
questions.explanation_correct: Construct a 60-degree angle, then construct a 45-degree angle (by bisecting 90 degrees) adjacent to it. 60 + 45 = 105 degrees.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Options B, C, and D have wrong arithmetic. Only 60 + 45 = 105 is correct.

questions.question_text: Sanjay draws segment PQ = 9.6 cm. He constructs its perpendicular bisector, which meets PQ at M. What is PM?
questions.explanation_correct: M is the midpoint of PQ. PM = PQ ÷ 2 = 9.6 ÷ 2 = 4.8 cm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The perpendicular bisector meets the segment at its midpoint. PM = 9.6 ÷ 2 = 4.8 cm.

questions.question_text: Neha bisected an angle of 60 degrees, then bisected one of the resulting angles. What angle did she finally get?
questions.explanation_correct: First bisection: 60 ÷ 2 = 30 degrees. Second bisection: 30 ÷ 2 = 15 degrees.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 60 ÷ 2 = 30 (first bisection), then 30 ÷ 2 = 15 (second bisection).

questions.question_text: Aisha needs to find the midpoint of a line segment without measuring. Which construction should she use?
questions.explanation_correct: The perpendicular bisector of a segment passes through its midpoint. Constructing it reveals the exact midpoint without needing to measure.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The perpendicular bisector construction finds the midpoint automatically — it is the point where the perpendicular bisector intersects the segment.

questions.question_text: Rohan draws a circle of radius 6 cm and marks a chord of length 6 cm. What type of triangle is formed by the two radii and the chord?
questions.explanation_correct: The two radii are each 6 cm and the chord is also 6 cm. So all three sides are equal, forming an equilateral triangle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Two radii = 6 cm each, chord = 6 cm. All three sides equal means it is an equilateral triangle.

questions.question_text: Using compass constructions, which of these angles can be obtained by starting from a 60-degree construction?
questions.explanation_correct: From 60 degrees: bisect to get 30, bisect again to get 15, double to get 120. All of 15, 30, and 120 can be derived from a 60-degree construction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 20, 25, and 35 degree angles cannot be constructed by bisecting or doubling 60 degrees. Only multiples and repeated halves of 60 (like 30, 15, 120) are obtainable.

questions.question_text: The perpendicular from an external point to a line is the shortest distance from that point to the line.
questions.explanation_correct: The perpendicular distance from a point to a line is always the shortest distance. Any other line from the point to the line would be longer (it would be the hypotenuse of a right triangle).
questions.explanation_incorrect: This is a fundamental geometric fact. The perpendicular from a point to a line gives the minimum distance.

questions.question_text: Divya wants to construct a line segment that is the sum of two segments of lengths 3.7 cm and 4.5 cm. What should the total length be?
questions.explanation_correct: Total length = 3.7 + 4.5 = 8.2 cm. She would draw one segment, then extend it by the second length using a compass.

questions.question_text: An angle of 150 degrees can be constructed as:
questions.explanation_correct: Construct a straight angle (180 degrees), then construct a 30-degree angle at the vertex. The remaining angle on the other side is 180 - 30 = 150 degrees.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Options B, C, and D do not give 150 degrees. Only 180 - 30 = 150 is correct.

questions.question_text: Tanvi draws two circles from the same centre, one with radius 3 cm and another with radius 5 cm. The region between the two circles is called a/an:
questions.explanation_correct: The region between two concentric circles is called an annulus (or ring).
questions.explanation_incorrect: A sector is a 'pizza slice' region. A segment is between a chord and an arc. A semicircle is half a circle. The region between two concentric circles is an annulus.

questions.question_text: Rahul constructs the perpendicular bisector of AB = 12 cm. He then marks a point P on the perpendicular bisector such that PM = 5 cm (where M is the midpoint of AB). What is the length PA?
questions.explanation_correct: M is the midpoint of AB, so AM = 6 cm. PM = 5 cm and PM is perpendicular to AB. Triangle PMA is right-angled at M. By Pythagoras: PA = √(AM² + PM²) = √(36 + 25) = √61 cm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: AM = 12 ÷ 2 = 6 cm. Triangle PMA has a right angle at M. PA² = AM² + PM² = 36 + 25 = 61. So PA = √61 cm.
